{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3306964,"name":"Jayveer Kochhar","username":"Emb3rr","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-11T10:31:22.913Z","cooked":"

Hi, this is my first topic here, and I figured to ask here due to the nature of the question itself. I am a part of an FTc team and this offseason was looking to create a custom pathing and trajectory following system and since many ftc teams dont to this I figured it would be more relevant for frc teams to answer.

A lot of trajectory creation algorithms I see online(and the one roadrunner uses I presume) is using either an S curve or trapezoidal motion profile for a straight line path and then fitting it to a spline or any other kind of path. But isnt this a rather cheap solution to a more complicated problem because especially mecanum drivetrains behave slightly differently in the x and y directions. Hence wouldnt it be more effective to create a different profile for either each wheel or for x, y and turn.

If this is the case, I tried thinking of a solution but it seems that you cant use a trapezoidal motion profile for this and would need some other kind of solution. could anyone help me out with this and how I could overcome this issue.

Also lastly, would this be the case for a coaxial swerve as well and would the same pathing work for that as well.
